page.title: 03Personal Recollections
page.content: An Older Person's Account (of changes in the area in his lifetime) Some changes took place in Byley when water was supplied. Years ago people had to carry water from a pump, and on washday, from a brook. Then electricity came instead of paraffin lamps. There were no bathrooms, just a tub in front of the fire hearth. Cows used to be milked by hand but now it is done by machine. Shire horses were used for farm work, now tractors are used. Corn was cut by binder, now with a combine harvesters. During World War Two, Air Forces of Britain and America were stationed in Byley. An aircraft hangar and runways still exist and there are American war graves in the churchyard. I have seen the M6 motorway built. The Church Hall was built recently, and the village school has been modernised.
